text:
What's a girl to do...? :thinking_face:

I have a gut feel on this, but I'm working with a client in a fairly competitive niche (_learning platforms_) with a rather unusual product "category" as a result of focusing on a niche/use case (_compliance_) - which means they don't really have any direct competitors - and am second guessing myself as to how to go about researching the keywords for the product & solution pages.

What approach to keyword do you take? Is it the same or different to how you go about researching keywords for content? If so, how so/why?

text:
I'd start with Google...

1. who else is writing about these topic?
2. what are the related search terms
3. what's the featured snippet?
4. is there video content ahead of posts & pages?

text: I’d start with the end user/customer. How do they talk about the needs and pains that the product is solving? How does that relate to the features and benefits that the client is highlighting as important? When making a buying decision, what questions is the user looking to answer? How are they credentialising solutions?

text:
I've asked the same question to people I know who have (and for the same reason as you).

General feeling is:
1. you get people you already know to help promote (so there's little gain there). 
2. it's *a ton* of effort to get to top 3 (which is the only way PH is worth it)
3. when you report back, you realise it's mostly vanity stats and there's little attribution to conversions/ROI.
All second-hand experience, and might be specific markets only. But, that's what I've learned from 5/6 sources.

Although, my team found it was easier to get to the 2nd position but that was only because we are part of a partner network (within Shopify). Group sharing and personal reach-outs also made a difference.

text: FWIW, we've worked with ~50 companies marketing to engineers and I only recall one instance of a company making a serious play to target HN.  (It didn't do anything for them.)  That's not to say that it _couldn't_.  I mean, I personally brought a lot of traffic to my own engineering blog from reddit and HN over the years.  But organic is a much more blue chip (if boring) strategy, and communities like DEV, where you can build a following, are much less all-or-nothing for establishing a founder as an influencer.  I'd think of it as an investment portfolio: organic is blue chip, community sites are overseas funds, and aggregators like HN/reddit are IPOs/venture capital.  19 out of 20 do absolutely nothing and 1 rocket ships.

Or, is that something you would put out a survey for (that’s not as explicit but will get that information from customers)? Or is there another method to successfully getting those answers?

elements.text: I don’t mean to interrupt this thread! But

text: Sales team and customer success teams are great sources of information for gathering needs and pains, they would usually be my first port of call. Sales teams should also understand the buying group, credentialising, and objections. Beyond that, talking to current customers directly is a great way of understanding how they made their buying decision, and what information was valuable to them, and when. I’d always recommend direct conversation/interviews, rather than surveys or online research.

elements.text: Sales team and customer success teams are great sources of information for gathering needs and pains, they would usually be my first port of call. Sales teams should also understand the buying group, credentialising, and objections. Beyond that, talking to current customers directly is a great way of understanding how they made their buying decision, and what information was valuable to them, and when. I’d always recommend direct conversation/interviews, rather than surveys or online research.

text: Oh, I’ve also run workshops that put product, sales and customer success together to collect that information in a single session. A lot of up front effort to get the right people in the room, but it can be super valuable outputs.

elements.text: Oh, I’ve also run workshops that put product, sales and customer success together to collect that information in a single session. A lot of up front effort to get the right people in the room, but it can be super valuable outputs.

text: <@UUXMLB9C7> thank you! All very interesting approaches. Would your workshops directly relate to the product or would they be more related to the overarching brand?

elements.text: thank you! All very interesting approaches. Would your workshops directly relate to the product or would they be more related to the overarching brand?

text: Most of the companies I’ve worked with are B2B companies with multiple solution sets, complex sales cycles, and large buying groups, so it’s mostly focused on what the product(s) do for customers, rather than the brand as a whole. Most of the effort is getting folks to shift away from centering their marketing around what they want to say about their product/service/brand to instead being most customer focused, understanding their needs and pains, using language that they understand, and sharing information that they might actually care about.
